text: So the presentations Richard as well as that's our briefly motivate the problem setting and provide details of a particular active inference instantiation under consideration today, which is the discrete state space setting.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the second half of the presentation is going to be focused on some particular examples comparing
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: the active inference formulation with reinforcement learning, specifically Q-learning and Bayesian model-based algorithm.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then what I'm going to do is provide some face validity of particular aspects of why you would want to even use active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So what is active inference?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's a first principle account of how biological or artificial agents may operate in dynamic non-stationary settings.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It stipulates that these agents, in order to maintain homeostasis, reside in attracting states that minimise their entropy or their surprise.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So if you take this particular example that we're seeing of this past little hungry agent opening the fridge, the way it would work is like you would need to, why would you open the fridge?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Right?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So you want to make a particular choice between eating at home or outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And in order to do that, you have to decide what is the optimal action that would allow you to resolve your own uncertainty about the current stage of affairs.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, and that would help you then decide whether you want to cook at home or you want to walk to the restaurant.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this particular instance, this has led to the agent opening the fridge to check whether it even has food at home.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And what's nice about active inference is that it allows you to think about these problem settings in a more formal way by specifying that optimal behavior is determined by evaluating the evidence that is the sensory input under the agent's gender model of observations that it is being exposed to.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And in this particular presentation, what we'll do is focus on just the process theory that underwrites active inference and not talk through the biological or the neural plausibility of the active inference message passing scheme.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But to properly motivate why we would want to even use active inference in comparison to generic reinforcement learning algorithms, we need to first start off with this understanding that with an active inference, there's this commitment to a pure belief-based scheme.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: which means that reward functions are not always unnecessary because any policy that you would have has epistemic value even in the absence of preferences.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Additionally, active inference agents can also learn their own reward functions and this helps the agent describe the type of behaviour that it expects to see in itself as opposed to something that it would get from the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And these two particular points are really important in contrast to reinforcement learning, because under standard RL settings, the reward function would define how the agent interacts or behaves within a particular environment setting.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But defining that reward function in the first place is quite difficult because it assumes that there is a specific signal that's being given from the environment
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: that can be unanimously good or bad for the agent, which wouldn't necessarily hold true in a real setting where these environment signals can change depending on the setting.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For example, eating ice cream is not always going to be rewarding if you're ill and it might make you worse.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that's why constructing these reward functions in the first place is extremely difficult.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And if you're not constructing them in an appropriate way, even with an RL setting,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: it can result in suboptimal behaviour for your agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And active inference is really good in the sense because we are actually replacing or bypassing the traditional reward function that you would have in the RL setting with prior beliefs about preferred outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the sort of desire states of affairs that you want to see yourself be in.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this becomes important in settings where there's no reward or there's really imprecise understanding of what a reward or preference setting should look like.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And in this scenario, within the standard action inference discrete state formulation, what we can do is learn the empirical prior distribution over these preferred outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: and intrinsic, sorry, the internal reward function of that agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this sort of brings me to like the first distinct conceptualization between RL setting and active inference, because within active inference, rewards are nothing distinct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They're just a standard observation that the agent is getting from the environment, whereas in RL, they're quite necessary to have appropriate action
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: that the agent is going to learn.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The second point we wanted to make was that active inference provides a principal account of epistemic exploration and intrinsic motivation as minimizing uncertainty.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And again, within the RL setting, this is quite crucial because the whole premise of like lots of new algorithms that we see in RL is to try and
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: find the right trade-off or the balance between exploration and exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So what are the right set of actions that the agent should make at a given point in time?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Should it carry on choosing all the different ice cream flavors that it's never been exposed to, like mustard, et cetera?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or should it always have the same ice cream flavor that it's been exposed to in the past that it really likes?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For example, hazelnut on a teller, for instance.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So this is an outstanding problem within RL and under a Bayesian framework, active inference deals with it naturally using the expected free energy formulation that I'll come to in a moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the last bit that you can see within the active inference framework is that it naturally accounts for uncertainty as part of the belief updating process.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So now that I've sort of laid out the three things that are super interesting about the active inference scheme in comparison to RL, I'm going to provide some intuitions as to why you can, sorry, some motivations as to why we can even formulate the active inference formulation the way we do.

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: In active inference, when we formulate the problem, we formulate it as a partially observable Markov decision process, because in this way, we are able to formulate a gender model that defines this internal distribution over the internal states that the agent would use in order to infer the outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it doesn't have access to the true state, but it can make hypothesis of beliefs about the states that could have given rise to a particular sense outcome space that it's being exposed to.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: or like a happy face that they're being exposed to.

text: So, and this is realized by deriving the probability of any policy by applying a softmax function over the expected free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this sort of illustrates the self-evidencing behavior of active inference, because any sort of policy or action sequence that results in lower expected free energy are more likely.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And intuitively, this would make sense because the expected free energy is sort of encapsulating all the types of things that you want to include or consider when you're interacting with the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So you want to explore, you want to exploit, but you want to have a balance of that.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then when you're selecting your policy, it's just a matter of determining the set of actions which get you closest to this particular goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this can be defined by an attractor set that's defined by your C matrix that we described before.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And if you don't have that, then it's just random exploration that you would get.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Sometimes you can also include a temperature parameter beta here.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And by having a hyper prior on this, you introduce an additional complexity cost into the expected free energy formulation, which allows you to account for how flat or how confident or precise you want your preferences to be over the policy space.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The key thing to note is that
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For the sake of simplicity, I'm not going to go through a lot of the details about how these are optimized, but you can do that in multiple different ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For example, in active inference, we can optimize the expectation about the hidden states of interest, the policies, the precisions through inference, and then we can also optimize the model parameters through the learning procedures involved.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But those sort of differ depending on the setup you're looking at.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For example, if you're using variational phase, you would just iterate these functions or objective functions until convergence.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or in active inference, you do a gradient descent to find the sufficient statistics of interest.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Again, this depends on exactly which formulation and setup you're looking at.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But the key thing to note here is that there's three particular aspects to the active inference algorithm that are useful and can be taken from this particular
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: framework and apply to other settings.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So I'm just going to reiterate and summarise them briefly.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we first have the gender model that's crucial.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So in order for an agent to interact and minimise a surprise, it needs a gender model of the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that's described as simply, I'm not including any of the model parameters here, but you can have your outcomes, your states and your policies.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And these are decomposed into, sorry, there's a
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: error with the brackets here, but these are decomposed into your prior, your likelihood and your transition function.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then once you have this general model, the objective of the agent is to fit the model to sample observations to reduce surprise, and that is through variational free energy optimisation.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So this particular trade-off that we have between the complexity and the accuracy cost
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then the last part of this algorithm is to plan.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So select actions that minimize uncertainty.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: That is the expected free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the way you do that is by having a softmax over this negative of g, the quantity we have here, and then sampling from that in order to select the next best action.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So that's it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: quick deep dive into a massive amount of active inference literature, but just wanted to highlight that those are the three core ingredients that if you are interested in implementing these algorithms yourself.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Okay.

text: I think because the way the RL agent is learning how to interact with the environment is through a reward function.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So anything where you don't really have that or you have an environment that is changing.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But I know that there's a whole host of people within the RL community working on intrinsic motivation or internal motivation.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So those sort of things do overlap with the active inference formulation.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But particular paradigms, I think, for me, the more interesting aspect of active inference comes from the fact that when you start thinking about
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: biological agents and if you're modeling a patient or someone with schizophrenia you can with this Bayesian framework you can change the priors to try and see how the person is interacting where I guess it's that it could be that their policy like the way they're valuing their policies are broken or it just could be other parts that are different but I think within the RL setting if you
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: are stepping outside the, um, the standard, the game mode, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So like magic core gym environments and start going into ones which are more open-ended and you don't have any rewards, then active inference could be potentially useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But I'm a little bit hesitant to just say whether it will be better because if you start augmenting Bayesian RL with all sorts of interesting components, then
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: to a certain extent, it will be active inference scaled up, which is potentially a contentious point.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But I think it depends on exactly what you are incorporating.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that's why for this particular presentation and our work, we were quite careful in defining what reinforcement learning meant, which is that you have to have this reward function in play and you want to maximise this reward function.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But if you sort of bypass them, say, okay, I'm just going to add in all sorts of interesting components to make the algorithm or the way the agent interacts with the environment, I guess, as similar to an active inference framework, or perhaps even better, then you don't, that framework
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: find distinction between where RL is better or where active inference is better, sort of, it's not really there for me.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Because I think both communities, from my perspective of working for similar things, which is sequential decision making.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And with our work, it's mostly with sequential decision making in the face of uncertainty, whereas some of our work might, RL work might not be focused on that.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So I think it's when you start

text: drawing the boundaries, it becomes a little bit hazy where things are separate or not.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I think what's important to understand is in the limit of like exploring the entire environment, your epistemic uncertainty is going to go to zero, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02
